identificationModule.briefTitle: Examining Digital Health Care Delivery Models Through Medicaid Collaborative
identificationModule.officialTitle: The Medicaid Innovation Collaborative (MIC) Experience: Transforming Care Through Digital Health: A Mixed Methods Analysis

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The purpose of this study is to examine the intervention effectiveness and dissemination of digital health care delivery models for improving selected health outcomes in the Medicaid population.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: The investigators will conduct a mixed method study that includes a controlled interrupted times series (CITS) design to study hypertension (HTN) and diabetes, a cohort to study pregnancy, and longitudinal patient and provider interviews to study experiences. This approach is appropriate when randomization is not desirable or feasible and is frequently utilized for evaluation of public health interventions (Lopez Bernal et al., 2018; Hategeka et al., 2020).

armGroups.label: OSF HealthCare
interventionNames: Behavioral: digital health delivered multicomponent intervention

armGroups.description: Subjects from Eagle View Community Health System enrolled in MIC Program

interventionNames: Behavioral: digital health delivered multicomponent intervention

interventions.name: digital health delivered multicomponent intervention
interventions.description: The MIC program will have set minimum levels of connectivity for each of the three defined conditions under study.
otherNames: Digital Care Solution as supportive personalized care

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in participant's blood pressure control at three points in time
primaryOutcomes.description: Decrease in the average systolic and/or diastolic blood pressure

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in participant's glycemic control at three points in time
primaryOutcomes.description: Defined as a reduction \>1% in glycosylated hemoglobin (hemoglobin A1C)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Patient Assessment of Chronic Illness Care scale (PACIC) from baseline to exit from program
primaryOutcomes.description: Measure of patient's perception of care management for chronic disease - 20 items on a 5-point scale 1=no or never to 5=Always, with higher score indicating better care
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: baseline, end of program, on average of 1 year

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Patient Perception of Health Care Management (adapted form of PACIC to reflect pre/postnatal care) from baseline to exit from program
primaryOutcomes.description: Measure of patient-centered care and self-management - 20 items on a 5-point scale 1=no or never to 5=Always, with higher score indicating better care
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: baseline, end of program, on average 6 months

primaryOutcomes.description: Measure of patient's satisfaction, Participant's recommendation of program to others (Yes/No)
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: at exit from program, on average 1 year

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Patient of one of four medically qualified health care centers and/or OSF HealthCare as defined by insurance type
* Insured by Medicaid or dually eligible for Medicare or Medicaid
* Has one or more of the three following conditions:

Hypertension, Diabetes Mellitus, or Pregnancy

* Able to read and understand English or read translated materials in language provided (e.g. Spanish)
* Minors who are pregnant and less 18 years of age who are enrolled in the MIC Program

Exclusion Criteria:

* Not enrolled in the MIC Program
* No one will be excluded on basis of sex or race
eligibilityModule.studyPopulation: The study population will be comprised of individuals who are enrolled in a digital health care delivery model for improving selected health outcomes in the Medicaid population. The population will be obtained from the cohorts as listed above. All those enrolled in the MIC program will be strategically identified and used as the population from which to draw the sample for the quantitative and qualitative portions of the study.
